children.name: when it is sb’s job or duty to do sth
be responsible for
children.definition: / have responsibility forB2  if you are responsible for or have responsibility for doing sth, it is your job or your moral or legal duty to do it: chịu trách nhiệm về
examples: ▪ The CEO is responsible for the day-to-day operation of the company.
▪ Why is it in our society that women are primarily responsible for raising children?
▪ The Navy has responsibility for the defense of the island.
▪ The health minister has overall responsibility for Britain’s hospitals.

children.name: be up to
children.definition: if sth is up to you, you are the person who is supposed to do it: đảm nhiệm
examples: ▪ She’s done her part of the job. The rest is up to Phillip.

children.name: it is up to sb to do sth
examples: ▪ It is up to the teacher to keep the class quiet and working hard.

children.name: be in charge of
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈtʃɑːʳdʒ ɒv/  to be the person who controls something and is responsible for it: phụ trách
examples: ▪ Who’s in charge of the club’s finances?
▪ The UN officer is in charge of coordinating all refugee programs in the region.
▪ The agency in charge of enforcing Mexico’s gun laws declined requests for an interview.

children.name: take care of
children.definition: /lookafterUK  to be responsible for a particular part or area of an organization, process, system etc: chăm sóc, phụ trách
examples: My assistant takes care of all the travel arrangements - you’ll have to ask him.
Sally looks after the accounts, and I’m in charge of the building itself.

children.name: the onus is on sb
children.definition: if the onus is on sb to do sth important or to make sure that sth important is done, it is their responsibility to do it, without waiting to be helped or told to do it: trách nhiệm, gánh nặng
examples: ▪ The onus of restarting the economy is on the government.

children.name: the onus is on sb to do sth
examples: ▪ The onus is on the taxpayer to make sure they pay enough tax.
▪ At university the onus is on you to work hard - no one is going to force you.

children.name: sth that is your job or your duty to do
responsibility
children.definition: a duty to be in charge of someone or something, so that you make decisions and can be blamed if something bad happens :
examples: Kelly’s promotion means more money and more responsibility.
responsibility for
The Minister has responsibility for the National Health Service.
with responsibility for sth
a manager with responsibility for over 100 staff
it is sb’s responsibility to do sth
It’s your responsibility to inform us of any changes.
It is a manager’s responsibility to set clear expectations for his or her employees.

children.name: have responsibility for
children.definition: doing
examples: sthThe Council has responsibility for maintaining the streetlights.

children.name: take responsibility for
children.definition: doing
examples: sthWho do you trust to take responsibility for our country's defence?

children.name: take on responsibility
children.definition: alsoassume responsibilityformal
examples: (= start to have responsibility for something )These days men tend to take on more responsibility at home.|The government must assume greater responsibility for the care of the elderly.

children.name: shoulder responsibility
children.definition: agree to start having a difficult or unpleasant duty
examples: The city, she said, would shoulder responsibility for caring for the children.

children.name: shirk responsibility
children.definition: not accept a duty you should accept
examples: He doesn't shirk responsibility.

children.name: exercise responsibilityformal
children.definition: take action because you have responsibility for something
examples: The citizens of ancient Athens met here to exercise their responsibility to govern themselves.

children.name: abdicate responsibilityformal
children.definition: refuse to have responsibility for something you used to have responsibility for
examples: The state should not allow parents to abdicate responsibility for their children.

children.name: the responsibility lies with somebody
children.definition: they are responsible for it
examples: Ultimate responsibility for admissions lies with the Course Co-ordinator.

children.name: personal responsibility
examples: So far, no one had taken personal responsibility for the project.

children.name: overall responsibility
examples: The Department of Education has overall responsibility for schools and universities.

children.name: direct responsibility
children.definition: when no other person is involved
examples: He has direct responsibility for all the programmes on Radio 1.

children.name: sole responsibility
children.definition: not shared with others
examples: The financial director has sole responsibility for financial matters.

children.name: collective responsibility
children.definition: shared equally by a group of people
examples: Head teachers should encourage a sense of collective responsibility among teachers.

children.name: primary responsibility
children.definition: most important responsibility
examples: I have primary responsibility for the children.

children.name: ultimate responsibility
children.definition: responsibility for making a final decision
examples: The National Assembly will have ultimate responsibility for ensuring that health targets are met.

children.name: a burden of responsibility
children.definition: a lot of responsibility, that worries you
examples: Being the only wage earner put a great burden of responsibility on my father.

children.name: a position of responsibility
children.definition: a job in which people depend on you to tell them what they should do
examples: Before the age of 21 he had attained a position of responsibility in the factory.

children.name: sb’s job
children.definition: spoken something that someone is responsible for doing: công việc của tôi
examples: ▪ I’m not doing the shopping - that’s your job.
▪ Agency employees must enforce regulations once they’re approved. That’s their job.

children.name: it’s sb’s job to do something
examples: ▪ It’s my job to make sure all the guests are comfortable.

children.name: sb’s duty
children.definition: sth that sb is officially, morally, or legally responsible for doing: nhiệm vụ
examples: ▪ I don’t give out parking tickets because I like to - it’s my duty.

children.name: it is sb’s duty to do sth
examples: ▪ I think it’s your duty to tell her what you know.
▪ My duty as a police officer is to find out the facts and communicate them to the proper people.

children.name: do your duty
examples: ▪ As the families wept openly, the prosecutor urged the jury to do its duty and convict Ballenger.

children.name: burden
children.definition: sth difficult or worrying that you are responsible for: gánh nặng
examples: ▪ Running the business on my own can be a burden at times.

children.name: burden of doing sth
examples: ▪ The minister has the burden of explaining why he must raise taxes.

children.name: heavy burdena very difficult burden: gánh nặng nghiêm trọng
examples: ▪ She has three children and heavy financial burdens at home.

children.name: carry a burdenhave that responsibility
examples: ▪ Carrying the burdens of leadership is never an easy task.

children.name: mission
children.definition: sth that you feel you must do because it is your dutySYN calling,vocation:
examples: Tom’s mission was to help young people in his local community.

children.name: with a mission
examples: She's a woman with a mission and she's absolutely determined to finish the project.

children.name: mission in life
examples: His main mission in life is to earn as much money as possible.
My mission in life is to educate the rich about the suffering of the poor.

children.name: duty
children.definition: sth that you have to do because it is morally or legally rightSYN obligation:
examples: I promise I willdomyduty.
We feelit is our duty tohelp her.

children.name: have a duty to do sth
examples: Parents have a duty to make sure that their children receive an education.

children.name: do your duty
examples: I felt I had done my duty by voting.

children.name: fulfil your dutyBritish English,fulfill your dutyAmerican English formal
children.definition: do what is needed
examples: The school has failed to fulfil its legal duty towards students.

children.name: have/owe a duty to somebody
examples: A tenant owes a duty to the landlord to keep the house in reasonable condition.

children.name: fail in your duty
children.definition: not do something that you should do
examples: I would be failing in my duty if I didn't warn you of the dangers.

children.name: a moral duty
examples: She felt it was her moral duty to treat everyone equally.

children.name: a legal duty
examples: Employers have a legal duty to ensure the safety of their workforce.

children.name: a statutory duty
children.definition: required by law
examples: Local authorities have a statutory duty to ensure that parks are clean.

children.name: a public duty
children.definition: relating to the people of a country
examples: The media has a public duty to report the truth.

children.name: a civic duty
children.definition: done because you live in a place
examples: It is your civic duty to vote.

children.name: a sense of duty
examples: He was caring for his parents out of a sense of duty rather than love.

children.name: be duty-bound to do sthformal
children.definition: have a duty to do something
examples: Soldiers are here to do a job and are duty-bound to complete it.

children.name: obligation
children.definition: a moral or legal duty to do sth : nghĩa vụ
examples: obligation to
America’s obligation to its allies
a sense of obligationthe sense of obligation that you feel towards your family

children.name: have an obligation
examples: Citizens have an obligation to obey the law.

children.name: feel an obligation
examples: When his mother died, he felt an obligation to continue her work.

children.name: meet/fulfil/honour an obligation
children.definition: do sth that you have a duty to do
examples: The company has been unable to meet its financial obligations.|All member states must fulfil their obligations according to the EC treaty.|The government failed to honour its obligations under the terms of the agreement.

children.name: impose an obligationformal
children.definition: put someone in the position of having an obligation
examples: A contract imposes certain obligations on employees and employers.

children.name: owe an obligation to somebodyformal
children.definition: have an obligation to support, help etc someone
examples: He owed an obligation of loyalty to his king.

children.name: an obligation arisesformal
children.definition: starts to exist
examples: the obligations arising out of the treaty

children.name: be under an obligation
children.definition: have an obligation
examples: The landlord is under an obligation to repair the house.

children.name: be under no obligation
examples: An accused man is under no obligation to say anything.

children.name: a moral/legal/social obligation
examples: We have a moral obligation to take care of our environment.

children.name: a statutory obligationformal
children.definition: something that the law says must be done
examples: The Local Authority has a statutory obligation to provide education.

children.name: a contractual obligation
children.definition: something that a contract says you must do
examples: The company must refund your money in line with their contractual obligations.

children.name: a binding obligation
children.definition: something that you must legally do, especially because of an agreement
examples: These clauses are legally binding obligations on both parties.

children.name: charge
children.definition: responsibility for controlling or looking after something
examples: _Her ex-husbandhaschargeofthe children during the week and she has them at the weekend.
_His boss asked him totakechargeofthe office for a few days while she was away.

children.name: commitment
children.definition: noun
examples: [ C ] something that you must do or deal with that takes your time
_family/work commitments
_I've got too many commitments at the moment to do an evening class.
_Children are such a commitment.

children.name: liability
children.definition: nounRESPONSIBILITYtrách nhiệm pháp lý, nghĩa vụ pháp lý
examples: [ U ] when you are legally responsible for something

children.name: liable
children.definition: adjectiveRESPONSIBLE

children.name: specializedhaving (legal) responsibility for something or someone
examples: _The law holds parents liable if a child does not attend school.
_If we lose the case we may be liablefor(= have to pay) the costs of the whole trial.

children.name: accountable
children.definition: adjective

children.name: Someone who is accountable is completely responsible for what they do and must be able to give a satisfactory reason for it
examples: _She is accountable onlytothe managing director.
_The recent tax reforms have made government more accountableforits spending.
_Politicians should be accountabletothe public who elected them.

children.name: lie
children.definition: verbPOSITIONlying,lay,lain
examples: If responsibility, blame, adecision, a choice,etc. lies with someone, they have responsibility, must make the decision, etc.
_Responsibility for the disaster must ultimately liewiththe government.
_Where does the blame lie?

children.name: at your own risk
children.definition: atyourown risk

children.name: used to mean that you are responsible for any damage, loss or difficulty
examples: _Owners are reminded that they leave their cars here at their own risk.

children.name: be stuck with sb/sth
children.definition: be stuck withsb/sth

children.name: to have to deal with someone or something unpleasant because you have no choice or because no one else wants to
examples: _We were stuck with him for the entire train journey!

children.name: saddle sb with sth
children.definition: saddlesbwithsthphrasal verbinformal
examples: to give someone a responsibility or problem which they do not want and which will cause them
a lot of work or difficulty
_The company is saddled withdebt.

children.name: to agree to be responsible for sth
take on
children.definition: to agree to be responsible for sth, especially sth that will make you have a lot of work or pressure: tiếp nhận
examples: I’m very busy. I’m afraid I can’t take anything else on at the moment.
Alice always seems willing to take on extra work without complaining.

children.name: assume responsibility for
children.definition: formal to take responsibility for sth that must be done: nhận trách nhiệm
examples: The ship’s owner has assumed responsibility for cleaning up the oil spill.
It was natural for Richard, as elder son, to assume responsibility for the family.

children.name: shoulder
children.definition: to agree to take responsibility for sth that will be difficult to deal with: gánh vác

children.name: shoulder responsibility/debts/the cost/burdens
examples: ▪ The burden of supporting the poor is shouldered mainly by charities.
▪ The company is unwilling to shoulder the cost of installing a daycare center.
